Cell.Data: If some concepts in the text are unclear or do not make sense, try looking that concept up in this xml as the text in this xml serves as an encyclopeadia you have a good chance of finding it. Unclear terms can be found in the AoW_Glossary. Do not change anything that is between [ and ] because it could break the hyperlink and strip it of its function. Anything between straight brackets - i.e. [ ] - is a formatting tag. Do not change these tags and keep them in the same relative position in the text. Anything between curly brackets - i.e. { } - is a place where text or numbers will be inserted by the game. Do not change the tag, but feel free to change its position in the text to suit the localized text.

A [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Unit’s[/hyperlink] abilities define its capabilities and weaknesses. Abilities include attacks, defenses and means of supporting allies and debilitating enemies. Abilities are the elements that compose a unit. There are two main types of ability:[br/][br/][hyperlink,000003AC000000AA]Active Abilities[/hyperlink]: these are actions that the unit can use during [hyperlink,000003AC0000025E]Tactical Combat[/hyperlink].[br/][br/][hyperlink,000003AC000000C6]Passive Abilities[/hyperlink]: these are always enabled on the unit, and can be positive or negative.[br/][br/][hyperlink,0000039E00000063]Unit Mods[/hyperlink] can enhance existing abilities or give new abilities to a unit.

Some [hyperlink,000003AC000000A8]Abilities[/hyperlink] have a cooldown to prevent them from being used on every [hyperlink,000003AC0000025E]Tactical Combat[/hyperlink] turn. During the cooldown period, a [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Unit[/hyperlink] will be unable to use the ability. Some abilities can only be used once per combat, and will remain on cooldown until the next battle.

A [hyperlink,000003AC00000336]Player[/hyperlink] can absorb a [hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colony[/hyperlink] that doesn’t belong to them, transferring ownership of that colony from the original owner to the player that is absorbing it. The colony’s race will not change when it is absorbed. The ‘Absorb’ action, found in the sector information panel of the colony center, is only available when a player is [hyperlink,000003AC000002EF]Occupying[/hyperlink] a [hyperlink,000003AC000000E0]Colony Center[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]Absorbing a colony takes 3 turns, but if you are at war with the player whose colony you are absorbing, the duration increases to 6 turns + 1 turn per province sector of that colony, of which there can be 4. If you end a war during the process of absorbing a colony of the player you are at war with, the colony is immediately absorbed.

Accuracy is the chance an attack will hit its intended target during [hyperlink,000003AC0000025E]Tactical Combat[/hyperlink]. If it fails, the attack will either [hyperlink,000003AC0000030D]Miss or Graze[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]An attack will always have a graze chance of up to 25%. This applies to all attacks that have less than 100% chance to hit. Any percentage from 99% to 75% will have a graze chance of 1% to 25% respectively. Below 75% hit chance, the attack will start to have a chance to instead miss completely.[br/][br/]The table below has examples of some hit chances and their possible outcomes.[br/][br/]Chance to Hit[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]Possible Outcome[line/][br/][tab/]90%[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]90% Hit; 10% Graze[br/][tab/]75%[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]75% Hit; 25% Graze[br/][tab/]40%[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]40% Hit; 25% Graze; 35% Miss

Action points are a unit’s capacity for performing tasks, allowing them to unleash repeated attacks, use abilities and move around the battlefield.[br/]During [hyperlink,000003AC0000025E]Tactical Combat[/hyperlink], all units will have a maximum of 3 action points that they can spend to use [hyperlink,000003AC000000A8]Abilities[/hyperlink].[br/][br/][hyperlink,000003AC00000333]Moving[/hyperlink] costs move points, but the unit will also spend action points when they move certain distances.[br/][br/][hyperlink,000003AC000000AA]Active Abilities[/hyperlink] can use various amounts of action points depending on the ability, and will (with some exceptions) always remove all remaining action points, no matter the initial cost. For example, if a unit has 3 action points and uses an ability that only requires one, it will still use all of its action points.[br/][br/][hyperlink,000003AC000002E6]Guard Abilities[/hyperlink] are common to all units, and these only use a single action point. When units enter this mode, they gain a defensive bonus, and end their turn.[br/][br/][hyperlink,000003AC000000C8]Overwatch[/hyperlink] conserves a unit’s current action points to attack with their main offensive ability when an enemy enters the overwatch zone.

Active abilities are the [hyperlink,000003AC000000A8]Abilities[/hyperlink] a [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Unit[/hyperlink] uses during [hyperlink,000003AC0000025E]Combat[/hyperlink] to cause damage, inflict [hyperlink,000003AC000000CB]Status Effects[/hyperlink], place [hyperlink,000003AC00000322]Combat Hazards[/hyperlink], or even protect and heal allies. Damaging abilities always have a [hyperlink,000003AC00000290]Damage Channel[/hyperlink] associated with it, and show their base damage amount on the ability tooltip.[br/]Some of these abilities have [hyperlink,000003AC000000DA]Cooldowns[/hyperlink] or can only be used once per tactical combat, and so cannot be used on sequential turns.[br/][br/]Each active ability as its own [hyperlink,000003AC0000028D]Action Point[/hyperlink] cost, but all of your remaining action points are consumed when you use an ability, unless it is a free action ability or similar.[br/][br/][hyperlink,000003AC000002E6]Guard Abilities[/hyperlink] are active abilities that all units have. They can be used to protect the unit from incoming damage by making it harder to hit or by shoring up its defenses.[br/][br/][hyperlink,000003AC000000C8]Overwatch[/hyperlink] can be used to defend a zone against approaching enemies. Note that not all units have this ability.

When an [hyperlink,000003AC0000009B]Army[/hyperlink] engages in combat with another, the combat will include armies from both parties that are on adjacent [hyperlink,000003AC000000BD]Hexes[/hyperlink] to the hex or [hyperlink,000003AC000000CD]Location[/hyperlink] on which combat was [hyperlink,000003AC000000C0]Initiated[/hyperlink].[br/]In addition, armies from players that are in an [hyperlink,000003AC00000034]Alliance[/hyperlink] with either side will also participate in combat.[br/][br/]If combat is initiated on a hex adjacent to a player’s [hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colony[/hyperlink], combat will take place on the colony.[br/][br/]Certain [hyperlink,000003AC00000338]Dominant Locations[/hyperlink] require the army to enter the structure, in these cases, the adjacent hex rule won’t apply. These fights can be challenging, so always bring your best army to these locations!

AI (Artificial Intelligence) players are [hyperlink,000003AC00000336]Players[/hyperlink] in the game that are controlled by the computer. AI players can be set to various difficulty levels before starting a game, each level influencing their in-game behaviour in different ways. The difficulty settings range from Very Easy to Very Hard, the easiest and toughest difficulty settings respectively.

[hyperlink,000003AC00000336]Players[/hyperlink] in an [hyperlink,000003AC00000034]Alliance[/hyperlink] can achieve a shared victory by working together towards a [hyperlink,000003AC00000324]Victory Condition[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]Allied victory can be enabled or disabled before starting a scenario.

A [hyperlink,000003AC000000C2]Forward Base[/hyperlink] can be [hyperlink,000003BD00001316]Annexed[/hyperlink] to any [hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colony[/hyperlink] that it is eligible to be part of by using the ‘Annex Forward Base as Sector’ action. This action becomes available when a forward base is within two sectors of a colony and is adjacent to either the colony or one of its [hyperlink,000003BD00001314]Province Sectors[/hyperlink]. The action is found in the sector information panel of the forward base sector, with a separate action showing for each colony that the forward base is eligible to be part of.[br/][br/]The action will be blocked and appear greyed out when the forward base sector is eligible to be annexed to a colony, but that colony cannot accept it as a province sector, such as when the colony has reached its sector limit. For more information about sector limits, see [hyperlink,000003BD000016D8]Colony Expansion[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]Annexing a forward base takes 1 turn. This action can be aborted at any time prior to completion.

Annexing a sector will attach that sector to a [hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colony[/hyperlink]. A sector can be annexed only if the colony has room to accept it, see [hyperlink,000003BD000016D8]Colony Expansion[/hyperlink]. [hyperlink,0000039E00000076]Sectors[/hyperlink] can be annexed to a colony if they are within two sectors of the [hyperlink,000003AC000000E0]Colony Center[/hyperlink] and are adjacent to another sector of that same colony. [br/][br/]Once attached to a colony, the economic benefits of the sector will be added to that colony’s income.[br/][br/]Some sectors can contain [hyperlink,000003AC00000338]Dominant Locations[/hyperlink] which will need to be taken over either by force or diplomacy before the sector can be annexed to a colony.[br/][br/]Annexing a sector is done by moving a unit onto the sector flag and choosing the ‘Annex Sector as Province to Colony’ button.

Arc Weapons harness the power of lightning and electrocute everyone and everything that dares to be on the wrong end of the barrel. The arc weapons group uses the Arc [DamageWave/] [hyperlink,000003AC00000290]Damage Channel[/hyperlink]. Arc Weapon abilities include damaging multiple enemies, stunning, and statically charging units.[br/][br/]Ethereal, Mineral, and Plant units are resistant to the arc damage channel; Mechanical units are weak to it.

In [hyperlink,000003AC0000025E]Tactical Combat[/hyperlink], some [hyperlink,000003AC000000A8]Abilities[/hyperlink] can affect multiple hexes. These abilities normally target everything within those hexes, meaning that they will also affect friendly [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Units[/hyperlink] in the target area. Units and [hyperlink,000003AC00000320]Obstacles[/hyperlink] inside the area of effect that have a red outlined hex will be affected by the ability.

Armor and shields influence the [hyperlink,000003AC00000292]Damage[/hyperlink] a [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Unit[/hyperlink] takes. The higher these values, the lower the damage the unit will receive from attacks.[br/][line/][br/]When dealing Psionic damage with an attack, a unit’s Armor[armor/] is ignored.[br/]When dealing damage with a melee attack, a unit’s Shields[shield/] are ignored.[br/][line/][br/]The armor and shield amount of a unit can be increased by equipping it with certain [hyperlink,0000039E00000063]Unit Mods[/hyperlink].

An army is a group of up to six [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Units[/hyperlink] located on a single [hyperlink,000003AC000000BD]Hex[/hyperlink] on the [hyperlink,000003AC000000CC]Strategic Map[/hyperlink]. Players can [hyperlink,000003AC0000028E]Move their Armies[/hyperlink] across the strategic map to explore new territories, find locations or vanquish foes.[br/]An army can then capture and occupy these [hyperlink,000003AC000000CD]Locations[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]An army can attack another army by moving onto the hex of the hostile army. The attacking player or entity can then choose between [hyperlink,000003AC000002EE]Manual and Auto Combat[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]Managing armies can be done through the Military Overview interface.[br/][br/]Armies can belong to [hyperlink,000003AC00000336]Players[/hyperlink], [hyperlink,0000039E00000075]NPC Factions[/hyperlink] or [hyperlink,000003AC000000A3]Marauders[/hyperlink].

Attack squads are raiding [hyperlink,000003AC0000009B]armies[/hyperlink] consisting of strong [hyperlink,0000039E00000075]NPC faction[/hyperlink] units. While at [hyperlink,000003AC00000284]war[/hyperlink], NPC factions will send attack squads to the opposing player’s colonies to attack their armies and domain. If the player does not deal with these squads, their colonies may be conquered.

When an [hyperlink,000003AC0000009B]Army[/hyperlink] tries to move beyond its maximum [hyperlink,000003AC000000DC]Move Points[/hyperlink] in a [hyperlink,000003AC0000002E]Turn[/hyperlink], a red pathway will appear. If a [hyperlink,000003AC000000BD]Hex[/hyperlink] is selected along the red pathway, that army will remember it and move along that path at the end of the next turn when they regain their move points.[br/][br/]If that army’s path is blocked (by another army, for example) as it goes through the [hyperlink,000003AC000002FE]Fog of War[/hyperlink], the army will stop and will ask for a new path.

Biochemical Weapons range from all sorts of weaponized acidic and noxious substances that corrode any armor with ease. The biochemical weapons Group uses the Bio [DamageBio/] [hyperlink,000003AC00000290]Damage Channel[/hyperlink]. Bio Weapons mods can change the damage channel of the attacks of modded units. Biochemical Weapon abilities include slowing, immobilizing, and Melting Armor.[br/][br/]Ethereal Units are resistant to the Biochemical damage channel; Mineral units are weak to it.

During a [hyperlink,000003AC00000038]war[/hyperlink], players can call NPC factions to join the war, as long as they have a [hyperlink,000003AC0000027F]relation state[/hyperlink] of Friendship or integration with them. This is done through a [hyperlink,0000039A00000930]NPC dwelling[/hyperlink] and is only available if the players at war have both encountered the NPC faction before. [br/][br/]Calling a NPC faction to war costs energy and [hyperlink,000003AC0000001B]influence[/hyperlink]. Unlike a call to war between players, NPC factions will always accept the call if the cost is paid. Once accepted, the NPC faction will go into the [hyperlink,000003AC00000284]war[/hyperlink] NPC relation state with the opposing player.

During a [hyperlink,000003AC00000038]war[/hyperlink], you can request that AI-controlled players with whom you share a [hyperlink,000003AC00000034]defensive pact[/hyperlink] or [hyperlink,000003AC00000034]alliance[/hyperlink] attack your target. Requesting attacks can help initiate aggression in war and thin out enemy forces.[br/][br/]The AI player will attempt to attack an automatically selected target for several turns and will give estimates on when they will reach the target. If they fail to reach the target, in that time or the target is already defeated, they will end their pursuit. If they succeed, they will notify the player. Only AI players that are already at war with the target can be called to arms. Calling an ally to arms costs [hyperlink,000003AC0000001B]influence[/hyperlink].

During a [hyperlink,000003AC00000038]war[/hyperlink], players can call other players with whom they share a [hyperlink,000003AC00000035]defensive pact[/hyperlink] or [hyperlink,000003AC00000034]alliance[/hyperlink] to join the conflict. The receiving player has 3 turns to answer the call, with two options:[bulletlist][bullet]They answer the call and declare war on the target to help their ally. The player does not receive any penalties for joining the war if they have no [hyperlink,000003AC00000031]Casus Belli[/hyperlink] towards the target.[/bullet][bullet]They decline the call and, in doing so, break the alliance.[/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]When two players share a defensive pact, they may only call their ally into a defensive war (a war which was declared upon them, rather than one they declared themselves)[br/][br/]If a call to war is declined, the diplomatic state is reverted to non-aggression and the declining player receives a [hyperlink,000003AC0000002F]reputation[/hyperlink] penalty. The requesting player also receives an [hyperlink,000003AC00000097]opinion[/hyperlink] penalty towards the declining player. A [hyperlink,000003AC000000EC]vassal[/hyperlink] player may never decline a call to war.

When selecting an [hyperlink,000003AC0000009B]Army[/hyperlink], there are two additional army actions besides movement available, found in the army interface: Guarding and Waiting.[br/][br/]Guarding removes an army from the list of armies that are awaiting orders. This is ideal when there is a [hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colony[/hyperlink] or [hyperlink,000003AC000000CD]Location[/hyperlink] that needs to be guarded; this leaves the army there without it requesting orders during strategic turns.[br/]Pressing the same button puts the army back in the list.[br/][br/]Waiting makes an army wait one turn before requesting orders again. This is helpful when waiting for reinforcements or when the army has some remaining [hyperlink,000003AC000000DC]Move Points[/hyperlink] but can’t reach the desired destination.

Settlements are locations found on the [hyperlink,000003AC000000CC]Strategic Map[/hyperlink]. They always belong to one of the main [hyperlink,000003AC000000C7]Races[/hyperlink]. Settlements can be convinced to join the your empire by spending influence, or they can be forcefully taken by engaging the defenders and defeating them.[br/][br/]Once the settlement has been acquired, various options for absorbing the settlement into a your empire will appear:[br/][bulletlist][bullet]Turn the settlement into a [hyperlink,000003AC000000E0]Colony Center[/hyperlink].[/bullet][bullet]Turn the settlement into a [hyperlink,0000039F00002DF6]Colonizer[/hyperlink].[/bullet][bullet]Absorb the [hyperlink,000003AC0000002D]Colonists[/hyperlink] of the settlement into an existing [hyperlink,000003AC000000E0]Colony Center[/hyperlink].[/bullet][/bulletlist]

A [hyperlink,000003AC00000336]Player’s[/hyperlink] capability ranking represents how they measure up against other players on the planet, separated into three different capability categories. Each category represents an aspect of a successful empire and can lead to their own [hyperlink,000003AC00000324]Victory Condition[/hyperlink].[br/][br/][bulletlist][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000271]Unity Capability[/hyperlink][/bullet][br/][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000272]Military Capability[/hyperlink][/bullet][br/][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000273]Development Capability[/hyperlink][/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]Players are ranked for their [hyperlink,000003AC00000317]Overall Capability[/hyperlink] and for each individual capability category. The ranking is determined using a variety of factors closely tied to each capability.[br/][br/]Capability rankings are shown in the ‘Victories and Quest’ interface. The ability to view the capability rankings is unlocked through the [hyperlink,000003BD000004BE]Area Surveillance[/hyperlink] research skill.

The ‘Capture and Annex Sector’ action becomes available when a [hyperlink,000003AC00000336]Player[/hyperlink] takes control of another player’s [hyperlink,000003BD000016D6]Province Base[/hyperlink] or [hyperlink,000003AC000000C2]Forward Base[/hyperlink] for the purpose of attaching it to one of their own [hyperlink,000003AC000000E0]Colony Centers[/hyperlink]. This action is available to sectors that are [hyperlink,000003AC000002EF]Occupied[/hyperlink] by the player but do not belong to them, and only when the sector is eligible to be attached to one of their colony centers. The action is found in the sector information panel.[br/][br/]Capturing a sector is only possible for sectors owned by other players. If the sector is already owned by the player that wants to attach it to a colony center, it is called [hyperlink,000003BD00001316]Annexation[/hyperlink] instead.[br/][br/]Capturing a sector from another player and annexing it to another colony center takes 3 turns. This action can be aborted at any time prior to completion.

Casus Belli, or justifications for war, represent a point value that are used to [hyperlink,000003AC000000E7]denounce[/hyperlink] players and [hyperlink,000003AC00000306]declare war[/hyperlink] on them. It is important to have Casus Belli against a player before declaring war to avoid large penalties in [hyperlink,000003AC0000002F]reputation[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,0000039F000024D9]Popular Support[/hyperlink]. Casus Belli are obtained when a player is actively provoked by another player, through [hyperlink,000003AC0000033C]fabrication[/hyperlink], or automatically by having low reputation or race relations. [br/][br/]Casus Belli[casusbelli/][tab/][largetab/][largetab/] Amount[tab/][largetab/][largetab/] Effect on Popular Support & Reputation[line/][br/] [tab/]Minor[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/][tab/]1 - 5[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/][tab/]+200 popular support, -200 reputation for 10[turn/][br/] [tab/]Moderate[largetab/][largetab/][tab/]6 - 10[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/][tab/]+300 popular support, -100 reputation for 15[turn/][br/] [tab/]Major[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/][tab/]11+[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/][tab/]+400 popular support for 20[turn/][br/][br/]Declaring war without Casus Belli lowers Popular Support, thereby reducing unit morale and colonist happiness. By having Casus Belli when declaring wars, the player gains Popular Support, increasing morale and happiness depending on the amount of Casus Belli. [br/][br/]Casus Belli are unique to each of the relations with other players. Casus Belli have a direct tie to [hyperlink,000003AC00000097]opinions[/hyperlink] as they form a [hyperlink,000003AC00000275]grudge[/hyperlink] that remains active until the Casus Belli are resolved. Aside from declaring wars, Casus Belli can be resolved through negotiation.[br/][br/]Automatic Casus Belli are received by having low reputation or race relations with the race of the opposing player. They can not be forgiven through [hyperlink,000003AC000000E4]negotiation[/hyperlink], but can be used in war declarations. Entering the final stage of a [hyperlink,000003AC00000324]Victory Condition[/hyperlink] will award Casus Belli to all players that are not currently in a [hyperlink,000003AC00000035]Defensive Pact[/hyperlink] or [hyperlink,000003AC00000034]Alliance[/hyperlink] with the player.

A newly-founded [hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colony[/hyperlink] has room to expand its [hyperlink,000003AC000000E0]Colony Center[/hyperlink] by building a central structure. However, due to space limitations in the colony center, only one of these central structures can be built.[br/][br/]Central structures provide a flat amount of income to help boost the economy of a developing colony. There is a central structure for each of the four resources:[br/][bulletlist][bullet][hyperlink,000003B500000967]Central Reactor Core[/hyperlink][largetab/] ([hyperlink,000003AC00000023]Energy[/hyperlink])[/bullet][br/][bullet][hyperlink,000003B500000964]Central Biofarm[/hyperlink][largetab/][largetab/]([hyperlink,000003AC00000022]Food[/hyperlink])[/bullet][br/][bullet][hyperlink,000003B50000096A]Central Replicator Factory[/hyperlink][largetab/]([hyperlink,000003AC0000003F]Production[/hyperlink])[/bullet][br/][bullet][hyperlink,000003B50000096D]Central Science Lab[/hyperlink][largetab/][largetab/]([hyperlink,000003AC00000025]Knowledge[/hyperlink])[/bullet][/bulletlist]

The arcadian clime is a fertile, temperate biome, the goal for many Star Union terraforming efforts on planets across the galaxy.[br/][br/]It is one of the main sector [hyperlink,000003BD00001313]Climes[/hyperlink], with economic potential in [hyperlink,000003AC00000022]Food[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003AC00000023]Energy[/hyperlink]. [hyperlink,000003AC000000C9]Researching[/hyperlink] the [hyperlink,000003B500000A04]Arcadian Exploitation[/hyperlink] research skill and building the [hyperlink,000003AC00000299]Colony Structure[/hyperlink] it unlocks will allow the player to generate income from this clime.[br/][br/]The economic potential of this clime can be exploited by creating a food or energy [hyperlink,000003AC000002A6]Sector Exploitation[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]Research also grants happiness bonuses to a colony for each arcadian sector within its [hyperlink,000003AC000002E4]Domain[/hyperlink].

The arctic clime is a frozen, harsh biome defined by heavy snow, ice cover and a layer of permafrost over the land.[br/][br/]It is one of the main sector [hyperlink,000003BD00001313]Climes[/hyperlink], with economic potential in [hyperlink,000003AC00000025]Knowledge[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003AC0000003F]Production[/hyperlink]. [hyperlink,000003AC000000C9]Researching[/hyperlink] the [hyperlink,000003BD0000001A]Arctic Exploitation[/hyperlink] research skill and building the [hyperlink,000003AC00000299]Colony Structure[/hyperlink] it unlocks will allow the player to generate income from this clime.[br/][br/]The economic potential of this clime can be exploited by creating a research or production [hyperlink,000003AC000002A6]Sector Exploitation[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]Research also grants happiness bonuses to a colony for each arctic sector within its [hyperlink,000003AC000002E4]Domain[/hyperlink].

The arid clime is a dry, sweltering biome, and while it generally lacks water, a few oases can be found where life can bloom.[br/][br/]It is one of the main sector [hyperlink,000003BD00001313]Climes[/hyperlink], economic potential in [hyperlink,000003AC00000023]Energy[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003AC0000003F]Production[/hyperlink]. [hyperlink,000003AC000000C9]Researching[/hyperlink] the [hyperlink,000003BD00000082]Arid Exploitation[/hyperlink] research skill and building the [hyperlink,000003AC00000299]Colony Structure[/hyperlink] it unlocks will allow the player to generate income from this clime.[br/][br/]The economic potential can be exploited by creating an energy or production [hyperlink,000003AC000002A6]Sector Exploitation[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]Certain research can also grant happiness bonuses to a colony for each arid sector within its [hyperlink,000003AC000002E4]Domain[/hyperlink].

The volcanic clime is a hostile, dangerous biome typically located around recent volcanic eruptions and lava flows. Its inherent harmful properties can be negated using technology.[br/][br/]It is a sector [hyperlink,000003BD00001313]Clime[/hyperlink] with no specific economic potential. Most races have difficulty operating in volcanic regions, and suffer economic penalties of -50% income from that sector if they attempt to colonize it. These penalties can be negated with certain [hyperlink,000003AC000000C9]Research[/hyperlink].

Coast sectors are water sectors that are adjacent to at least one land sector. Coasts are one of the water sector [hyperlink,000003BD00001313]Climes[/hyperlink], which has economic potential in [hyperlink,000003AC00000023]Energy[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003AC00000022]Food[/hyperlink]. [hyperlink,000003AC000000C9]Researching[/hyperlink] the [hyperlink,000003B500000398]Aquatic Development[/hyperlink] research skill and building the [hyperlink,000003AC00000299]Colony Structure[/hyperlink] it unlocks will allow the player to generate income from this clime.[br/][br/]The economic potential can be exploited by creating a water [hyperlink,000003AC000002A6]Sector Exploitation[/hyperlink].

The fungal clime is a wild, overgrown biome full of strange flora and fauna, the result of introducing non-native fungal species for their aesthetics. They have now taken over whole swathes of the planets on which they were spread.[br/][br/] It is one of the main sector [hyperlink,000003BD00001313]Climes[/hyperlink], with economic potential in [hyperlink,000003AC00000025]Knowledge[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003AC00000022]Food[/hyperlink]. [hyperlink,000003AC000000C9]Researching[/hyperlink] the [hyperlink,000003BD00000079]Fungal Exploitation[/hyperlink] research skill and building the [hyperlink,000003AC00000299]Colony Structure[/hyperlink] it unlocks will allow the player to generate income from this clime.[br/][br/]The economic potential can be exploited by creating a research or food [hyperlink,000003AC000002A6]Sector Exploitation[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]Certain research can also grant happiness bonuses to a colony for each fungal sector within its [hyperlink,000003AC000002E4]Domain[/hyperlink].
Ocean is one of the two water [hyperlink,000003BD00001313]Climes[/hyperlink] a sector can have. Ocean sectors are [hyperlink,000003AC000002B9]Uninhabitable[/hyperlink].

[hyperlink,0000039E00000076]Sectors[/hyperlink] each contain a clime associated with two of the four main [hyperlink,0000039F00002DF4]Resources[/hyperlink]. Each clime has economic potential that can be unlocked via [hyperlink,000003AC000000C9]Research[/hyperlink]. The exceptions to this rule are the [hyperlink,000003AC000002CE]Volcanic[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003AC00000325]Ocean[/hyperlink] climes, which are not linked to any specific resource.[br/][br/]The climes and their associated resources are as follows:[br/][bulletlist][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC000002C8]Arcadian[/hyperlink][largetab/][largetab/](Food and Energy)[/bullet][br/][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC000002C9]Arctic[/hyperlink][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/](Knowledge and Production)[/bullet][br/][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC000002CA]Arid[/hyperlink][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/](Energy and Production)[/bullet][br/][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC000002CC]Fungal[/hyperlink][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/](Food and Knowledge)[/bullet][br/][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC000002CD]Coast[/hyperlink][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/](Food, Energy and Knowledge)[/bullet][br/][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC000002CE]Volcanic[/hyperlink][largetab/][largetab/](None)[/bullet][br/][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000325]Ocean[/hyperlink][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/](None)[/bullet][br/][br/]Players can also unlock global bonuses through research, which improve unit [hyperlink,000003AC0000030F]Regeneration[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003AC00000026]Colony Happiness[/hyperlink] with sectors of each clime.[br/][br/]A sector also contains one [hyperlink,000003AC000000D1]Terrain[/hyperlink], and any number of [hyperlink,000003AC000002BB]Special Features[/hyperlink].

Colonies are population centers for the main races, and are the primary sources of economic wealth and production for your empire. Colonies can cover up to five [hyperlink,0000039E00000076]Sectors[/hyperlink]; the [hyperlink,000003AC000000E0]Colony Center[/hyperlink] and a maximum of four [hyperlink,000003BD00001314]Province Sectors[/hyperlink] that are [hyperlink,000003BD00001316]Annexed[/hyperlink] to the colony center.[br/][br/]A colony is defended by a [hyperlink,000003AC0000029A]Colony Militia[/hyperlink], which can be upgraded by building colony militia [hyperlink,000003AC00000299]Colony Structures[/hyperlink] in the center.

[hyperlink,000003AC0000002D]Colonists[/hyperlink] are automatically managed by default. The colonist manager will even out colonists over the resource channels (pending slot availability) and will prevent both [hyperlink,000003AC00000022]Food[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003AC00000026]Happiness[/hyperlink] deficits.[br/][br/]Using the income tab in the [hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colony[/hyperlink] Interface, experienced players can fine-tune their colony’s output and adjust to sudden shifts in demand. The player has two options to influence colonist management. [br/][br/]In Automatic Mode, players can set a focus on individual resources. The colony will prioritize these resources, but will keep avoiding deficits. A resource can also be deprioritized, meaning their [hyperlink,000003AC000002B6]Colonist Slots[/hyperlink] will be the last to fill. Colonists will be equally distributed over colonist slots with the same priority.[br/][br/]Colonists can be manually assigned by turning the auto-system off. This gives full control over where colonists are placed via arrows per resource, which can add or subtract colonists from colonist slots.

When assigned to a resource slot, a [hyperlink,000003AC0000002D]Colonist[/hyperlink] provides +5 base income of that resource. This income can be increased by achieving higher [hyperlink,000003AC000002B8]Sector Levels[/hyperlink] in [hyperlink,000003BD00001314]Province Sectors[/hyperlink] that have been [hyperlink,000003AC000002A6]Exploited[/hyperlink] for one of the four main resources. Colonists that aren’t assigned to a resource are idle colonists, and do not provide any benefit to the colony.[br/][br/][hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colonies[/hyperlink] start with 4 colonist slots in each main resource that can be gained in a colony, apart from happiness. Additional colonist slots can be gained by exploiting sectors and raising their sector level.[br/][br/]Some [hyperlink,000003AC000002BB]Special Features[/hyperlink] also grant colonist slots when located in a colony.[br/][br/][hyperlink,000003AC000002BE]Unhappiness Events[/hyperlink] and hostile [hyperlink,0000039E00000071]Operations[/hyperlink] can cause some colonists to become [hyperlink,000003AC000002B4]Rioters[/hyperlink]. Rioters remain in their assigned resource slot, but do not produce any income and cannot be moved.

[hyperlink,000003AC0000002D]Colonists[/hyperlink] have an upkeep cost of 2 food and 1 happiness that ensures that they are happy and fed. Their upkeep cost is subtracted from the [hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colony[/hyperlink]’s income, noted in the tooltips of those resources.[br/][br/]If a colony produces less [hyperlink,000003AC00000022]Food[/hyperlink] than its colonists require for upkeep, starvation will start to build up. When starvation reaches a certain threshold, colonists will begin [hyperlink,000003BD000016D9]Starving[/hyperlink], which leads to colonists being removed from the colony.[br/][br/]If a colony produces less [hyperlink,000003AC00000026]Happiness[/hyperlink] than its colonists require for upkeep, unhappiness will start to build up. When unhappiness reaches a certain threshold colonists will begin [hyperlink,000003AC000002B4]Rioting[/hyperlink], which leads to loss of income and disabled [hyperlink,000003AC000002B6]Colonist Slots[/hyperlink].

A growing, happy population is essential for the re-colonization of the worlds of the Star Union, as population drives the economic performance and the [hyperlink,000003AC000002B7]Expansion[/hyperlink] of colonies. Population units are called colonists, and range from 1 colonist in the smallest outposts to about 20 in the largest metropolises.[br/][br/]A large portion of the variable income for colonies comes from assigning a number of colonists to a particular resource type. By turning on manual [hyperlink,000003AC000002B5]Colonist Management[/hyperlink], you can fine-tune your colony’s output and adjust to sudden shifts in demand.[br/][br/]A [hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colony[/hyperlink]’s population count is visualized next to the colony’s name on the world map. Colonist allocation per resource is accessed from the income tab in the colony interface.

Although still one of the [hyperlink,000003AC0000029B]Core Units[/hyperlink], Colonizers are the only units capable of creating new [hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colonies[/hyperlink]. Each race starts with one colony, and can start producing Colonizers from the beginning of the game. Each costs a colonist to create, but the advantage of a new colony is well worth it. Building Colonizers is expensive, and uses up many rare resources. Each colonizer you build will cost {energyCost}, {crystalCost} and {productionCost} than the one before it.[br/][br/]Do note that these units are the only ones without any [hyperlink,000003AC000000AA]Active Abilities[/hyperlink], making them extremely fragile. If the path to the new colony location is filled with danger, make sure this unit is not without military protection!

If a colony is captured by [hyperlink,000003AC0000031B]Independents[/hyperlink] the colony will become independent. When a [hyperlink,000003AC00000336]Player[/hyperlink] is [hyperlink,000003AC00000340]Defeated[/hyperlink] all existing colonies under their control will automatically become independent as well.[br/][br/]When a [hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colony[/hyperlink] belonging to a [hyperlink,000003AC00000336]Player[/hyperlink] faction becomes [hyperlink,000003AC0000031B]Independent[/hyperlink], its society will collapse due to the lack of a functioning government, and the colony will be consumed by anarchy.[br/][br/]While a colony is undergoing anarchy, opportunistic players can attempt to take control of it by moving an army onto it. Depending on how the colony turned independent, there are various ways a player can take control of it: diplomatically, economically or militarily. [br/][br/]After a certain number of turns of anarchy, depending on the size of the colony, the colony and all its sectors will be razed to the ground, and will be replaced by a [hyperlink,0000039A000010D7]Settlement[/hyperlink] of the race that used to inhabit the colony.

The colony center lies at the heart of every [hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colony[/hyperlink]. This is you can interact with and manage your colony and its [hyperlink,000003AC0000002D]Colonists[/hyperlink]. The colony center has a base income of [hyperlink,000003AC0000003F]Production[/hyperlink], [hyperlink,000003AC00000022]Food[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003AC00000026]Happiness[/hyperlink] that forms a solid foundation for the budding colony.[br/][br/]The income of all [hyperlink,000003BD00001314]Province Sectors[/hyperlink] is added to the colony center, where [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Units[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003AC00000299]Structures[/hyperlink] can be built. Some units require military structures to be built before they can be produced in a colony center.[br/][br/]The center is defended by the [hyperlink,000003AC0000029A]Colony Militia[/hyperlink]. When a colony center is [hyperlink,000003BD000016CD]Absorbed[/hyperlink] or [hyperlink,000003AC000002A0]Migrated[/hyperlink] by an enemy player, all [hyperlink,000003BD00001316]Annexed[/hyperlink] sectors are also lost.

To gain access to the environment around a [hyperlink,000003AC000000E0]Colony Center[/hyperlink] for exploitation, it needs to [hyperlink,000003BD00001316]Annex[/hyperlink] sectors as [hyperlink,000003BD00001314]Provinces[/hyperlink] under its control. The number of sectors a colony can administer depends on the number of [hyperlink,000003AC0000002D]Colonists[/hyperlink] living there.[br/][br/]Colonists[largetab/][largetab/]Sector Limit[largetab/][largetab/]Colony Name[br/]4+[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]2[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]Outpost[br/]8+[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]3[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]Town[br/]12+[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]4[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]City[br/]16+[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]5[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]Metropolis[br/][br/]Once the sector limit and size of a colony has increased, it can never decrease.[br/][br/]Sectors can only be annexed by a colony if they are within two sectors of the colony center and adjacent to another sector of that same colony. Once attached to a colony, the economic potential of that sector can be exploited.

As a colony population grows, it increases economic output and allows its colony to [hyperlink,000003BD00001316]Annex[/hyperlink] more [hyperlink,0000039E00000076]Sectors[/hyperlink]. The number of [hyperlink,000003AC0000002D]Colonists[/hyperlink] directly determines how much room there is for [hyperlink,000003BD000016D8]Colony Expansion[/hyperlink] and how many sectors a colony can administer.[br/][br/]A colony’s food income drives its growth. Food is collected each turn, and when the total amount of food collected reaches the colonist acquisition threshold, a new colonist is created. The colonist acquisition threshold is gradually raised as the colony gains more colonists.[br/][br/]The total number of [hyperlink,000003AC000002B6]Colonist Slots[/hyperlink] in a colony caps the number of colonists it can have. The number of colonist slots can be increased by annexing additional sectors and building structures. If, by special circumstance, a colony has more colonists than it has slots, the remaining colonists will become idle. Idle colonists cost upkeep, but do not generate any income.[br/][br/]Colonists have an upkeep cost of both [hyperlink,000003AC00000026]Happiness[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003AC00000022]Food[/hyperlink], so care must be taken to not allow a colony to grow too fast, as this can lead to [hyperlink,000003AC000002B4]Rioters[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003BD000016D9]Starvation[/hyperlink].

In addition to regular [hyperlink,000003AC0000009B]Armies[/hyperlink], colonies are defended by a colony militia. [br/][br/]During tactical combat, the colony militia spawns [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Units[/hyperlink] that only appear during battles when either the [hyperlink,000003AC000000E0]Colony Center[/hyperlink] or the [hyperlink,000003BD000016D6]Province Bases[/hyperlink] of its province sectors are attacked. All colonies have a basic colony militia as a defense force to protect them against small raiding parties. However, against larger hostile forces, it is advisable to also have an army defending the colony. Defeated or injured colony militia units are replenished at the start of the next strategic map [hyperlink,000003AC0000002E]Turn[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]The strength of the colony militia can be upgraded by building the following colony structures:[br/][bulletlist][bullet][hyperlink,0000034100000959]Colony Militia Barracks[/hyperlink][/bullet][br/][bullet][hyperlink,00000386000004C9]Company Militia Barracks[/hyperlink][/bullet][br/][bullet][hyperlink,00000386000004CD]Battalion Militia Barracks[/hyperlink][/bullet][/bulletlist]

[hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colonies[/hyperlink] use their production income to build [hyperlink,000003AC00000299]Structures[/hyperlink] for the [hyperlink,000003AC000000E0]Colony Center[/hyperlink] and its [hyperlink,000003BD00001314]Province Sectors[/hyperlink]. Structures can provide economic and military bonuses for the colony. Colonies can also produce [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Units[/hyperlink], an essential military presence for the [hyperlink,000003AC00000336]Player[/hyperlink]’s empire.[br/][br/]Everything that can be built has a [hyperlink,000003AC0000003F]Production[/hyperlink] cost. The colony’s production income is added to the current production project at the end of each turn. When the total production cost is fulfilled, the project is completed, and any remaining production income will overflow to the next project in the [hyperlink,000003AC00000295]Production Queue[/hyperlink]. Each colony has a single production queue, and can work on one thing at a time.[br/][br/]Colonies can also use their production income to generate [hyperlink,000003AC00000025]Knowledge[/hyperlink] or [hyperlink,000003AC00000023]Energy[/hyperlink] instead, which converts their production income into either of those resources.

Colonies can be upgraded by building colony structures improving the colony economically, defensively or otherwise. Colonies can produce structures for the [hyperlink,000003AC000000E0]Colony Center[/hyperlink] and for its [hyperlink,000003BD00001314]Province Sectors[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]Structures in the colony cost both [hyperlink,000003AC0000003F]Production[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003AC00000023]Energy[/hyperlink] to create.[br/][br/]Structures can be unlocked with [hyperlink,000003AC000000C9]Research[/hyperlink], by constructing a prerequisite building, or by annexing certain [hyperlink,000003AC00000338]Dominant Locations[/hyperlink] for the colony.[br/][br/]See also:[br/][bulletlist][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC000002A6]Sector Exploitation[/hyperlink][/bullet][br/][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC000002A7]Sector Specialization[/hyperlink][/bullet][br/][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000298]Colony Production[/hyperlink][/bullet][/bulletlist]

Battlefield Effects are [hyperlink,0000039E00000072]Tactical Operations[/hyperlink] that are active during [hyperlink,000003AC0000025E]Tactical Combat[/hyperlink], and usually have effects that aid the defender or hurt the attacker. [br/][br/]These effects are either constant or activate whenever the Battlefield Effect's timer runs out, A battlefield effect's timer can be seen below the effect in tactical combat. After triggering the timer resets. [br/][br/]Battlefield effects can be either only active in combat on a specific structure as with gold or silver [hyperlink,0000039E0000007A]Landmarks[/hyperlink] or in an affected sector as with [hyperlink,0000039C00001C1A]Hazards[/hyperlink].

Combat hazards are placed on hexes, during [hyperlink,000003AC0000025E]Tactical Combat[/hyperlink], and will trigger effects on any [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Units[/hyperlink] moving through an affected [hyperlink,000003AC000000BD]Hex[/hyperlink] or ending their turn on it.[br/][br/]They will often disappear after a certain amount of tactical turns, which can be seen by hovering over the hazard’s hex.

Commanders are the avatars of the players in Age of Wonders: Planetfall. Commanders are tasked with building an empire from the ashes of the Star Union. At the start of a game, the commander can be customized by choosing their race, appearance, secret technology, perks and faction banner. The chosen race and secret technology unlock unique research paths and are therefore the defining choices for the empire the commander will create.[br/][br/]During gameplay, commanders are their own unit on the planet: a [hyperlink,000003AC000000C1]hero[/hyperlink]. They have the same features as heroes: they can get new equipment, and they can be upgraded. However, instead of having to be revived when defeated, commanders return from[hyperlink,000003AC00000301]recuperating[/hyperlink] automatically.[br/][br/]Commanders are also the representative when engaging in [hyperlink,000003AC00000330]Diplomacy[/hyperlink]. The diplomatic choices the player makes will reflect in their opinions, popular support and reputation. These can vary greatly, depending on how the player decides to rule their empire.

Compliments and insults are direct [hyperlink,000003AC00000274]pronouncements[/hyperlink] used to change opinions of other player empires. Both options cost [hyperlink,000003AC0000001B]influence[/hyperlink] to send but have different effects:[bulletlist][bullet]Compliments increase the [hyperlink,000003AC00000097]opinion[/hyperlink] of the opposing player for a limited amount of turns, possibly steering them towards wanting better diplomatic states.[/bullet][bullet]Insults decrease the opinion of the opposing player for a limited amount of turns and give them a single [hyperlink,000003AC00000031]Casus Belli[/hyperlink] point towards the insulting player, which can provoke a war.[/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]Only one compliment or insult can be sent each turn.

A [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Units[/hyperlink] with concealment is invisible to enemy players on the [hyperlink,000003AC000000CC]Strategic Map[/hyperlink]. A unit will often only be invisible to others while on certain terrain types, while [hyperlink,00000345000006CF]Universal Camouflage[/hyperlink] makes a unit invisible in any terrain.[br/][br/]A concealed unit will be revealed to a player if it is adjacent to one of their normal units, within sight range of a unit that has the [hyperlink,0000039F000021AB]Detection[/hyperlink] ability, or through certain [hyperlink,000003AC00000099]Covert Operations[/hyperlink].

Core Units are the base [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Units[/hyperlink] of a [hyperlink,000003AC000000C7]Race[/hyperlink] or [hyperlink,0000039E00000075]NPC Factions[/hyperlink]. A player’s racial core units can be immediately produced at any [hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colonies[/hyperlink] without a special colony structure or research.[br/][br/]These units are always [hyperlink,000003AC000000D3]Tier I[/hyperlink].

Cosmite is rare material from beyond the Void, harnessed by the Star Union for highly advanced weapons and technology. It is a global strategic resource used for the building and [hyperlink,000003AC000000D4]Upkeep[/hyperlink] of Tier III and Tier IV [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Units[/hyperlink] and the purchase and equipping of [hyperlink,0000039E00000063]Unit Mods[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]Cosmite [hyperlink,0000039A00000924]Resource Nodes[/hyperlink] are the primary source of cosmite income and are relatively rare in the world, making it a highly valuable resource. A small amount of cosmite income can be generated by certain [hyperlink,000003AC00000299]Colony Structures[/hyperlink] that are unlocked through [hyperlink,000003AC000000C9]Research[/hyperlink].

The courier system can be used to transport [hyperlink,000003AC0000031C]Hero Equipment[/hyperlink] from [hyperlink,000003AC000002EC]Loot[/hyperlink] locations or from within a hero’s [hyperlink,000003AC000002E9]Inventory[/hyperlink] to other heroes. After selecting the hero, the item will be immediately delivered to that hero.

The chance to hit for all ranged attacks against a [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Unit[/hyperlink] that’s in cover is reduced by half if the cover is between the unit and the hex from which the attack originated.[br/]A land or floating unit enters cover when they enter a hex that is adjacent to a wall or [hyperlink,000003AC00000320]Obstacle[/hyperlink] during [hyperlink,000003AC0000025E]Tactical Combat[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]A half-full shield icon will appear at the border of the hex the unit is moving onto if that unit would benefit from cover from an adjacent obstacle.[br/]A full shield represents Full Cover, which blocks line of sight, preventing most attacks from targeting this unit.[br/][br/]A unit in cover can still use its [hyperlink,000003AC000000A8]Abilities[/hyperlink] as normal.[br/][br/]A [hyperlink,000003450000052C]Large[/hyperlink] unit cannot benefit from cover, but can serve as cover for smaller units.

Covert operations target other players rather than an army or colony. They are used for gathering information or sabotaging others in various ways without revealing yourself as the culprit.[br/][br/]Covert operations make use of [hyperlink,000003AC00000312]Operational Effectiveness[/hyperlink] and can also fail as a result, which will notify the targeted player of your actions. The success chance is based on how high the [hyperlink,000003AC000000E1]Operational Strength[/hyperlink] of the user is in comparison to the target’s [hyperlink,000003AC000000E2]Operational Defense[/hyperlink]. The higher the strength, the better the success chance. The higher the defense, the lower the chance of succeeding and remaining undetected.[br/][br/]All covert operations are unlocked by advancing through the [hyperlink,000003AC00000269]Operations Tech Group[/hyperlink], and cost energy and [hyperlink,000003AC0000002B]Strategic Operation Points[/hyperlink] to prime before they can be launched. Some of these operations require more strategic operation points than you have available. In these instances, the operation will consume strategic operation points on every following turn until it has accumulated enough to be primed.

A critical hit or a fumble can occur when a [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Unit[/hyperlink] uses an [hyperlink,000003AC000000AA]Active Abilities[/hyperlink] to damage another unit in [hyperlink,000003AC0000025E]Tactical Combat[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]When a unit critically hits, the attack deals 50% extra damage and is guaranteed to hit. If it was a repeating attack, all of the hits are considered critical hits.[br/][br/]When a unit fumbles, all [hyperlink,000003AC0000030D]grazes[/hyperlink] are converted to misses, and all hits are converted to [hyperlink,000003AC0000030D]grazes[/hyperlink]. If the attack cannot graze, then it will always miss.[br/][br/]Critical hits and fumbles are connected to a unit’s [hyperlink,000003AC000000C3]Morale[/hyperlink], but the chance can be modified by other unit abilities or by one of the unit’s [hyperlink,000003AC000000C6]Passive Abilities[/hyperlink].

Attacks can use one or more of six different damage channels (types). Those are [damagephysical/]Kinetic, [damagethermal/]Thermal, [damagebio/]Biochemical, [damageentropy/]Entropy, [damagewave/]Arc and [damagepsyche/]Psionic.[br/]When [hyperlink,000003AC00000292]Damaging Units[/hyperlink], it is important to know the target's [hyperlink,000003AC000002F6]Armor and Shields[/hyperlink] values and whether they have any [hyperlink,000003AC000002F5]Resistances and Weaknesses[/hyperlink] to particular damage channels.[br/]These channels also have [hyperlink,000003AC000000CB]Status Effects[/hyperlink] associated with them, and a unit that is resistant to that type of damage is also resistant to the associated status effect, lowering the chance it will apply to the unit.

In [hyperlink,000003AC0000025E]Combat[/hyperlink], units are damaged when affected by [hyperlink,000003AC000000AA]Active Abilities[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,0000039E00000071]Operations[/hyperlink], or by triggering certain enemy [hyperlink,000003AC000000C6]Passive Abilities[/hyperlink]. In all cases, damage is reduced by a unit’s [hyperlink,000003AC000002F6]Armor and Shields[/hyperlink] and its [hyperlink,000003AC000002F5]Resistance[/hyperlink] to certain [hyperlink,000003AC00000290]Damage Channels[/hyperlink]. A [hyperlink,000003AC000002F5]Weakness[/hyperlink] to a damage channel will increase the damage taken by the unit when it receives that type of damage, so always be sure to keep these in mind.[br/][br/]Damage is calculated using the following formula:[br/]Final Damage = Ability Damage x (0.9^((Armor + Shields + Resistance) - Weakness))

While in a [hyperlink,000003AC00000037]neutral[/hyperlink] diplomatic state or [hyperlink,000003AC00000036]non-aggression pact[/hyperlink], you can choose to declare war on another player through [hyperlink,000003AC00000330]Diplomacy[/hyperlink]. Trying to declare war from higher diplomatic states requires that the higher level pact to be broken first, taking 1 or 2 turns depending on the state. Declaring a war will bring both players into the [hyperlink,000003AC00000038]War[/hyperlink] Diplomatic State.[br/][br/]Declaring war affects the [hyperlink,0000039F000024D9]popular support[/hyperlink] of the player depending on the amount of [hyperlink,000003AC00000031]Casus Belli[/hyperlink] they have:[bulletlist][bullet]Declaring war without any Casus Belli leads to a high popular support penalty while the war lasts.[/bullet][bullet]Declaring war with Casus Belli grants popular support for a limited time.[/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]Declaring war on another player will always give them 1 point of Casus Belli which is combined with their existing Casus Belli and then used to affect their Popular Support.[br/][br/]AI controlled players tend to declare war when their opinion of a player is low and when they have Casus Belli.[br/][br/]Players can also declare [hyperlink,000003AC00000284]war[/hyperlink] on NPC Factions. This is done through [hyperlink,0000039A00000930]NPC Dwellings[/hyperlink].

A player suffers defeat when their [hyperlink,000003AC0000009D]Commander[/hyperlink] has fallen and their [hyperlink,000003AC000000E3]Headquarters[/hyperlink] is taken, when they [hyperlink,000003AC000000CE]surrender[/hyperlink], or when an opposing player achieves a [hyperlink,000003A70000000A]Doomsday Victory[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]In the Defeated state, all locations and units that were still owned by the defeated player will all become owned by the Marauder Faction. Defeated players can not perform any actions and will no longer get a turn. If the defeated player was the last opposing player, the other player will achieve the [hyperlink,000003AC0000026E]Conquest [/hyperlink]victory. A defeated player can never be brought back into the game.[br/][br/]Defeat by war can sometimes be prevented by offering a [hyperlink,000003AC000000EC]Vassalage[/hyperlink].

[hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colonies[/hyperlink] can build defense structures unique to each race. These structures provide turrets in specific locations on the colony’s citadel wall for use in [hyperlink,000003AC0000025E]Tactical Combat[/hyperlink] within the [hyperlink,000003AC000000E0]Colony Center[/hyperlink]. These turrets automatically fire at the start of each [hyperlink,000003AC00000304]Combat Round[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]The defensive structure that can be built in a colony depends on the [hyperlink,000003AC000000C7]Race[/hyperlink] of the colony, not the race of the [hyperlink,000003AC00000336]Player[/hyperlink].

Denouncements and warnings are [hyperlink,000003AC00000274]Pronouncements[/hyperlink] used to negatively affect reputation and opinion towards a player. Both pronouncements require Casus Belli to be in effect and can only be sent once per type of [hyperlink,000003AC00000031]Casus Belli[/hyperlink] until a war is declared. Denouncements require [hyperlink,000003AC0000001B]Influence[/hyperlink] while warnings are free. [br/][br/]Denouncements cause the following:[bulletlist][bullet]Any player that knows the opposing player receives an [hyperlink,000003AC00000097]Opinion[/hyperlink] penalty against them.[/bullet][bullet]The opposing player’s [hyperlink,000003AC0000002F]Reputation[/hyperlink] is reduced[/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]Warnings only lower the opinion of the opposing player towards the warning player. Unlike [hyperlink,000003AC000000E5]Insults[/hyperlink], denouncements and warnings do not give the opposing player a Casus Belli, preventing them from taking revenge with a justified war.[br/][br/]Denouncing using a [hyperlink,000003AC0000033C]Fabricated Casus Belli[/hyperlink] will not lower the reputation of the opposing player and instead gives them a Casus Belli againt the sending player instead. Fabricated Casus Belli cannot be used to warn a player.

Desertion occurs when a [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Unit[/hyperlink] has low [hyperlink,000003AC000000C3]Morale[/hyperlink] at the start of its owner’s turn. A unit that deserts vanishes completely and cannot be recovered.[br/][hyperlink,000003AC000000C1]Heroes[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,0000039F00002DF1]Mindless[/hyperlink] units cannot desert.[br/][br/]The table below shows the chances of a unit deserting at the start of a player's strategic turn.[br/][br/] Unit Morale[largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]Chance per Turn[line/][br/][tab/]-200[anger/][tab/][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]5%[br/][tab/]-400[anger/][tab/][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]20%[br/][tab/]-600[anger/][tab/][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/][largetab/]40%[br/][br/]

A [hyperlink,000003AC00000336]Player’s[/hyperlink] development capability represents their capacity for [hyperlink,000003AC000000C9]Research[/hyperlink] as well as their colony expansion and development. Players are compared to each other regarding these various aspects and are [hyperlink,000003AC000002B0]Ranked[/hyperlink] accordingly. Their ranking can change at any point during a [hyperlink,000003AC0000002E]Turn[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]The development capability is tied closely with the [hyperlink,000003A70000000A]Doomsday Victory[/hyperlink] condition and [hyperlink,000003A70000000B]Domination Victory[/hyperlink] condition.[br/][br/]The ability to view capabilities is unlocked through the [hyperlink,000003BD000004BE]Area Surveillance[/hyperlink] research skill.

When you meet other players on the planet; you can start to engage in diplomacy. Diplomacy allows players to make treaties and pacts, and to trade resources.[br/][br/]Through the Diplomacy interface, relations with players, NPC factions and races can be reviewed. The [hyperlink,000003AC0000009D]commander[/hyperlink]is the player representative in Diplomacy. The relationship between players is represented by their [hyperlink,000003AC00000097]opinion[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003AC0000003A]diplomatic state[/hyperlink]. Improving these through diplomatic actions can result in mutual benefits, like allowing a[hyperlink,000003AC00000310]call to war[/hyperlink]. Worsening these relationships can result a declaration of war. The following diplomatic actions are available in the Diplomacy interface:[bulletlist][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC000000E4]Negotiation[/hyperlink]: propose trades or diplomatic states[/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000274]Pronouncements[/hyperlink]: use influence to modify opinions[/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000306]Declaring war[/hyperlink][/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]NPC factions and independent settlements have separate interaction systems. See:[hyperlink,000003AC00000030]NPC Faction Relations[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,0000039A000010D7]Settlements[/hyperlink]

An alliance is the highest achievable [hyperlink,000003AC0000003A]diplomatic state[/hyperlink], that gives the most benefits and allows the allied players to work together towards the same goals to achieve victory. [br/][br/]An alliance pact unlocks the following:[bulletlist][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC000002F2]Share intelligence[/hyperlink] treaty[/bullet][bullet]Allies can be [hyperlink,000003AC00000310]called into any war[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC0000033B]Allied victory[/hyperlink][/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]Alliances have the following effects:[bulletlist][bullet]Increased [hyperlink,000003AC0000002F]Reputation[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet]Increased [hyperlink,000003AC00000097]Opinion[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet]Increased [hyperlink,000003AC00000286]Race relation[/hyperlink] with the race of the other player[/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]Players must first break this pact before they are able to [hyperlink,000003AC00000306]declare war[/hyperlink] on the opposing player. This takes 2 turns to complete.

The defensive pact is the second positive [hyperlink,000003AC0000003A]diplomatic state[/hyperlink], and unlocks additional treaties and the option to call the other player into defensive war when in need. [br/][br/]The defensive pact unlocks the following:[bulletlist][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC000002F3]Share vision[/hyperlink] treaty[/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000034]Alliance[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet]The other player can be [hyperlink,000003AC00000310]called to war[/hyperlink] when waging a defensive war[/bullet][bullet]Players now join each other in battle through the [hyperlink,000003AC000000B1]adjacent hex rule[/hyperlink][/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]Defensive pacts have the following effects:[bulletlist][bullet]Increased [hyperlink,000003AC0000002F]Reputation[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet]Increased [hyperlink,000003AC00000097]Opinion[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet]Increased [hyperlink,000003AC00000286]Race relation[/hyperlink] with the race of the other player[/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]Players must first break this pact before they are able to [hyperlink,000003AC00000306]declare war[/hyperlink] on the opposing player. This takes 2 turns to complete.

Neutral is the lowest non-hostile [hyperlink,000003AC0000003A]diplomatic state[/hyperlink] and is the default state for two players when meet each other. In the neutral state, players can either improve to a [hyperlink,000003AC00000036]non-aggression[/hyperlink] pact through negotiation, offer/demand [hyperlink,000003AC000000EC]vassalage[/hyperlink] or [hyperlink,000003AC00000306]declare war[/hyperlink] without any turn delay.[br/][br/]While in a neutral state, players cannot have any [hyperlink,000003AC000000EA]diplomatic treaties[/hyperlink].

The non-aggression pact is the first positive [hyperlink,000003AC0000003A]diplomatic state[/hyperlink], that shows peaceful intent between two players and unlocks new treaties.[br/][br/]The non-aggression pact unlocks the following:[bulletlist][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC000002F1]Open Borders[/hyperlink] treaty[/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000331]Good Neighbors[/hyperlink] treaty[/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000035]Defensive Pact[/hyperlink][/bullet][/bulletlist] [br/][br/]Non-aggression pacts have the following effects:[bulletlist][bullet]Increased [hyperlink,000003AC0000002F]Reputation[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet]Increased [hyperlink,000003AC00000097]Opinion[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet]Increased [hyperlink,000003AC00000286]Race relations[/hyperlink] with the race of the other player[/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]In this state players can still [hyperlink,000003AC00000306]declare war[/hyperlink], but suffer a 1 turn delay before they may attack the opposing player.

War is the state of open hostilities between two players, which means that they can freely attack eachother. War is preceded by a [hyperlink,000003AC00000306]Declaration of War[/hyperlink] from one of the players to the other. Declaring war may impact reputation and popular support depending on the justification of the war, called [hyperlink,000003AC00000031]Casus Belli[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]Being at war unlocks the following:[bulletlist][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000307]Truce[/hyperlink] treaty[/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000310]Call to war[/hyperlink] action[/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000311]Call to arms[/hyperlink], if one of the player’s allies participates in the same war[/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]Being involved in wars has the following effects:[bulletlist][bullet]Decreased [hyperlink,000003AC0000002F]Reputation[/hyperlink] depending on the Casus Belli[/bullet][bullet]Decreased [hyperlink,000003AC00000097]Opinion[/hyperlink] towards and from the opposing player[/bullet][bullet]Decreased [hyperlink,000003AC00000286]Race relations[/hyperlink] with the faction of the other race[/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]Wars can end or be halted in the following ways:[bulletlist][bullet]Forming a truce[/bullet][bullet]Requesting or demanding vassalage[/bullet][/bulletlist]

The diplomatic state represents the degree of mutual cooperation between two players. Diplomatic states further affect opinions, race relations and reputation. You can change your diplomatic states through [hyperlink,000003AC00000330]Diplomacy[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]Players can share the following diplomatic states:[bulletlist][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000034]Alliance[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000035]Defensive pact[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000036]Non-aggression pact[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000037]Neutral[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000038]War[/hyperlink][/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]As the diplomatic state between you and another player improves, you will have an increased base [hyperlink,000003AC00000097]opinion[/hyperlink] and will be able form better [hyperlink,000003AC000000EA]treaties[/hyperlink]. It also affects your [hyperlink,000003AC00000286]Race Relations[/hyperlink] with the race of the other player.[br/][br/]Your [hyperlink,000003AC0000002F]Reputation[/hyperlink] is affected by all diplomatic states with others. Having better diplomatic states increases reputation, whereas conducting war and breaking diplomatic pacts lowers reputation.

Selecting the disband icon on the [hyperlink,000003AC0000009A]Unit[/hyperlink] panel will disband the unit, causing it to instantly disappear. This function is useful when a [hyperlink,000003AC000000D4]Unit’s Upkeep[/hyperlink] becomes too high for your empire to maintain.

Doctrine Slots are used to indefinitely sustain [hyperlink,000003890000060F]Doctrines[/hyperlink]. Every player has several doctrine slots, limiting the number of doctrines you can have active at once. Additional doctrine slots can be acquired by unlocking the [hyperlink,000003BD000016D4]Empire Upgrades[/hyperlink] that grant doctrine slots, located in the [hyperlink,000003AC00000269]Operations Tech Group[/hyperlink].

The Doctrine Tech Group is where players can find all of the [hyperlink,000003890000060F]Doctrines[/hyperlink] they will be able to unlock through Research, as well as racial colony upgrades, both of which help in boosting either your economy or military.[br/][br/]The techs in this tech group change depending on which [hyperlink,000003AC000000C7]Race[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003AC00000329]Secret Technology[/hyperlink] you picked at the start of a game.

Doctrines are sustained operations that have a global effect on your entire empire and steer your empire’s military and society as a whole. To activate a doctrine, you must spend [hyperlink,000003AC0000002B]Strategic Operation Points[/hyperlink] and energy to prime it. Once primed, it becomes active until turned off. Every Doctrine takes up one of your [hyperlink,0000039F000024DA]Doctrine Slots[/hyperlink], and when all of your doctrine slots are filled, you are unable to activate any more until an active Doctrine has been turned off. New doctrines can be obtained by:[br/][bulletList][bullet]Researching the [hyperlink,000003AC00000267]Doctrine Tech Group[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet]Buying them from [hyperlink,0000039E00000075]NPC Factions[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet]Annexing gold and silver [hyperlink,0000039E0000007A]Landmarks[/hyperlink][/bullet][/bulletList]

Your domain comprises all [hyperlink,0000039E00000076]Sectors[/hyperlink] you control, including sectors not [hyperlink,000003BD00001316]Annexed[/hyperlink] to a [hyperlink,000003AC00000047]Colony[/hyperlink] but still under your control, such as [hyperlink,000003AC000000C2]Forward Base[/hyperlink] sectors and [hyperlink,000003AC00000338]Dominant Locations[/hyperlink].

A [hyperlink,000003AC000000CD]Location[/hyperlink] in the center of a sector is considered a dominant location. You must [hyperlink,000003AC000002A1]Raze[/hyperlink] or capture dominant locations captured or before the sector can be [hyperlink,000003BD00001316]Annexed[/hyperlink] as a province sector.

The domination victory is a territory-based military victory condition which is achieved when a [hyperlink,000003AC00000336]Player[/hyperlink] successfully captures a large part of the planet as their [hyperlink,000003AC000002E4]Domain[/hyperlink] and manages to defend it for a certain number of turns. The portion of the planet requiring capture for this victory can be set in map options prior to starting a game.[br/][br/]The player is required to maintain control of the set amount of the planet for 10 turns before they are [hyperlink,000003AC000000B5]Victorious[/hyperlink]. During those 10 turns, if they lose control over enough of their domain to bring them under the required amount, the domination victory is canceled.[br/][br/]All players receive [hyperlink,000003AC000002E5]Event[/hyperlink] notifications when a player’s domain is approaching the required amount to start the domination victory. This should give them ample warning that a player is approaching a domination [hyperlink,000003AC00000324]Victory Condition[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]The domination victory is closely tied to an empire’s [hyperlink,000003AC00000272]Military Capability[/hyperlink].

Each secret technology has a final, ultimate resort: a Doomsday Weapon. Doomsday Weapons can be unlocked through research, which grants the Doomsday Sector Upgrade and Doomsday Operation that can be used once the upgrade has been built in a [hyperlink,0000039E00000076]Sector[/hyperlink]. A total of three Doomsday Sector Upgrades can be built, with the second and third improving the Doomsday Operation further.[br/][br/]Once a player has built three Doomsday Sector Upgrades, they can prime and perform a finisher operation, cancelling all other existing Doomsday operations and making the effect of the player's Doomsday Weapon global. A timer will begin to count down a number of turns. Unless the Doomsday Weapon is stopped, when the counter hits 0, the owning player wins.[br/][br/]Each [hyperlink,000003AC00000329]Secret Technology[/hyperlink] has their own specific Doomsday Operation:[br/][bulletList][bullet][hyperlink,0000039A00000EA2]Final Revelation[/hyperlink] for [hyperlink,000003AC0000032E]Secret Tech: Celestian[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,0000038700002B49]Planetary Purification[/hyperlink] for [hyperlink,000003AC0000032F]Secret Tech: Promethean[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,0000038700002C4E]Oblivio Mundi[/hyperlink] for [hyperlink,000003AC0000032B]Secret Tech: Psynumbra[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,000003B500000197]The Singularity[/hyperlink] for [hyperlink,000003AC0000032D]Secret Tech: Synthesis[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,0000039A00000A07]Dimensional Cascade[/hyperlink] for [hyperlink,000003AC0000032C]Secret Tech: Voidtech[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,0000038700002ADC]Omega Awakening[/hyperlink] for [hyperlink,000003AC0000032A]Secret Tech: Xenoplague[/hyperlink][/bullet][/bulletList]

Doomsday structures unlock the potential of the [hyperlink,0000039F00002DF8]Doomsday[/hyperlink] weapons from each [hyperlink,000003AC00000329]Secret Technology[/hyperlink]. They are built in [hyperlink,000003BD00001314]Province Sectors[/hyperlink] and are represented on the [hyperlink,000003AC000000CC]Strategic Map[/hyperlink] as a structure in the [hyperlink,000003BD00001314]Province Sector[/hyperlink] of the colony in which they are built. Each colony can only have one doomsday structure within its [hyperlink,000003AC000002E4]Domain[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]They are unlocked via secret technology [hyperlink,000003AC000000C9]Research[/hyperlink] at the same time as the Doomsday Weapon operation.[br/][br/]Losing control over or disconnecting the province sector in which the doomsday structure is built will downgrade the level of the doomsday weapon, and will cancel any active [hyperlink,000003A70000000A]Doomsday Victory[/hyperlink] timers.

The doomsday victory is a technological victory that requires high level [hyperlink,000003AC000000C9]Research[/hyperlink] and a specialization in [hyperlink,000003AC0000003F]Production[/hyperlink] to achieve.[br/][br/]A doomsday victory is achieved when a [hyperlink,000003AC00000336]Player[/hyperlink] successfully launches their final [hyperlink,0000039F00002DF8]Doomsday[/hyperlink] operation and successfully defends their [hyperlink,000003AC000002AF]Doomsday Structures[/hyperlink] until it the operation is completed.[br/][br/]The player needs to defend their doomsday structures for 10 turns before they are [hyperlink,000003AC000000B5]Victorious[/hyperlink]. During those 10 turns, if they lose control of one of their doomsday structures, the doomsday victory is canceled.[br/][br/]Other players will receive [hyperlink,000003AC000002E5]Event[/hyperlink] notifications when a player is building doomsday structures and when the final doomsday operation is being prepared for launch. This should provide ample warning that a player is approaching their doomsday [hyperlink,000003AC00000324]Victory Condition[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]The research required to build the doomsday structures and launch the doomsday operation can be found in [hyperlink,000003AC00000266]Secret Tech[/hyperlink] research, at Tier IV and Tier X of the [hyperlink,000003AC000000CA]Research Tree[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]The doomsday victory is closely tied to an empire’s [hyperlink,000003AC00000273]Development Capability[/hyperlink].

Dwelling ownership can be bought through [hyperlink,000003AC00000279]Dwelling trades[/hyperlink] and gives a player full ownership of one of the [hyperlink,0000039A00000930]Dwellings[/hyperlink]. Owning a dwelling gives a player a large economic bonus.[br/][br/]There are multiple conditions for gaining dwelling ownership:[bulletlist][bullet]The relation state with the NPC faction needs to be [hyperlink,000003AC00000280]Integrated[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet]A nearby colony needs to be able to [hyperlink,000003BD00001316]annex[/hyperlink] the dwelling as a province sector[/bullet][bullet]The player has to pay a large amount of influence [/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]Once a dwelling is owned, it acts like any other [hyperlink,000003BD00001314]province sector[/hyperlink] except that it has the highest level of [hyperlink,000003AC000002A6]exploitation[/hyperlink] in a resource dependant on the faction. Dwelling trades can still be accessed through an owned dwelling and can even be accessed by [hyperlink,000003AC00000034]allied players[/hyperlink].[br/][br/]These dwellings remain owned even when the player decides to go to war with the faction later. In that case, there is a high chance that [hyperlink,000003AC00000288]attack squads[/hyperlink] will target the owned dwellings.
Removed 'access to producing NPC faction units and provides a' from the entry at the end of the first paragraph, where it mentions economic bonus, as this is no longer true.

Interact with a [hyperlink,0000039A00000930]dwelling[/hyperlink] through talking to a NPC stack and asking to speak to their leader(s) or clicking on the dwelling to access their trading options. Trading is only available if the [hyperlink,000003AC0000027F]relation state[/hyperlink] with the NPC faction is Neutral or higher. Additional trading options unlock once the relation state increases. Trading also increases the [hyperlink,000003AC0000033A]NPC favor[/hyperlink] with the faction. [br/][br/]The following items can be bought by trading with a dwelling:[bulletlist][bullet][hyperlink,0000039E00000075]NPC faction[/hyperlink] units[/bullet][bullet]Special [hyperlink,0000039E00000063]mods[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet]A unique [hyperlink,000003890000060F]doctrine[/hyperlink][/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000285]Dwelling ownership[/hyperlink][/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]Having a positive [hyperlink,000003AC0000002F]reputation[/hyperlink] reduces the cost of trade items, whereas a negative reputation increases the cost.

Dwellings are large [hyperlink,000003AC00000338]dominant locations[/hyperlink] on the planet that represent the headquarters of [hyperlink,0000039E00000075]NPC factions[/hyperlink]. Interacting with a dwelling will open up the dwelling interface, where the NPC faction relations can be reviewed. [br/]The following actions are available at a Dwelling:[bulletlist][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000279]Trading[/hyperlink] with the Dwelling[/bullet][bullet]Requesting [hyperlink,000003AC000000D9]Quests[/hyperlink] from the faction[/bullet][bullet]Declaring [hyperlink,000003AC00000284]war[/hyperlink] with the faction[/bullet][bullet]Requesting a [hyperlink,000003AC00000308]peace deal[/hyperlink] when at war with the faction[/bullet][bullet][hyperlink,000003AC00000332]Calling[/hyperlink] the faction to war against other players[/bullet][/bulletlist][br/][br/]For more information on the ownership of a dwelling and the effects it has, see: [hyperlink,000003AC00000285]Dwelling Ownership[/hyperlink]

When all dwellings belonging to an NPC faction have been captured, that faction becomes assimilated.[br/][br/]Assimilated NPC factions will no longer send [hyperlink,000003AC00000276]demands[/hyperlink], launch [hyperlink,000003AC00000288]attack squads[/hyperlink], or lose relationship with players for doing quests for other NPC factions.[br/][br/]Assimilated NPC factions will only offer [hyperlink,000003AC000000D9]quests[/hyperlink] and [hyperlink,000003AC00000284]faction war quest rewards[/hyperlink] to players who own a dwelling of theirs. Allied players who own an assimilated faction's dwelling can still ask for quests from this faction.

The economy tech group focuses on increasing your resource output and overall effectiveness on the Strategic Map.
